FRIDAY, APRIL 9, 1937

Everyone Should Attend
Every student who is interested in the recent Phi
Bete case—and who wants to do something about it—
should attend the protest meeting this afternoon at one
o'clock. And everyone should be interested. A goodly
portion of the student body is affected by Phi Beta
Kappa per se. But all of us should interest ourselves in
this case, because it is a real student problem. Whether
justified or not, the campus is interpreting the facts in
this case to mean that one must forgo this type of
academic recognition if one wants to be in the leadership of a progressive movement. And that is the impression which must be corrected—if there is no
foundation for it.
If there is any information to be obtained or ideas
to be exchanged, attend this meeting. If you think our
stand is unfair or unjustified, let us know. One of the
ways to settle this problem is to intelligently exchange
ideas and consider the situation carefully.
There is no doubt that in order to get something done
we have to crystallize our sentiment. We have to show
that we students are concerned with an apparent injustice for this case and to seek a non-recurrence in the
future.

Editorial In Verse
We have received a poem which expresses a sentiment
more effectively than a most verbose editorial. It makes
you stop and think about the motto of our University.
Just what are the practical implications of
"Veritas vos liberabit,"
This poem attempts to take an inventory of the
guiding ideal of our University. We do not necessarily
agree with all of its contentions, but are in accordance
with the spirit behind it.
"Veritas vos liberabit,"
The truth shall make you free!
0 men of Hopkins,
That meant something once
To our University.
Or did it?
At any rate,
It means very little now.
Let our Pilate ask,
What is truth?
Pilates have always asked that,
As they have barricaded themselves
Within the walls of their own smallness
And washed their hands in their own watery blood.
Even if truth
Be not absolute,
Even if it be only a propositional function,
Or only a frame of reference,
It is something more than a matter of politics,
Of personal pettiness,
Of pettifogging poltroons,
Of priggish pusillanimity.
If it be only a point of view,
Still must we look at it through hate-colored glasses?
And to me it seems
That if there is no truth,
There are some truths,
Honor, fair-mindedness, courage, strength.
If I am wrong,
It is a grand way to be wrong.
But, my friends,
When lucre becomes more than light
And animosity more than appraisal,
It takes more than truth to make you free.

Support The Peace Strike
With hardly three weeks left before this year's Student Strike against War, only twelve of the thirty-odd
eligible campus organizations have expressed any sympathy with its aims. Thus, more than half the more
active section of the student .body has no representation
on the strike committee.
Can it be that these organizations are opposed to
peace as a principle? But, in every poll on the question
in •the last few years, the Hopkins has manifested a
deep-seated distaste for Mars and all his works.
There is another more likely possibility. Is this
apathy indicative of the feeling that, behind the strike's
innocent exterior, subversive forces are moving? In
other words, the claim is that we who support the strike
have been duped by agents of some foreign ideology.
That contention is best answered by the list of organizations now represented on the committee. They are,
at last account, the Student Council, the Hullabaloo,
Omicron Delta Kappa, the NEWS-LETTER, the Debating
Council, -the Y.M.C.A., the Student Activities Committee,
Phi Sigma Delta, Phi Alpha, Phi Epsilon Pi, the Young
Communist League, and the American Student Union.
Of these, only the last two can, •by any stretch of the
imagination, be influenced by radical opinion. Three,
in fact, are social fraternities, traditionally the chief
object of attack from the left. The ratio is ten to two—
hardly an overwhelming preponderance for "unsafe"
opinions.
The truth is, of course, that the questions of war and
peace transcend political lines. Every decent citizen
hopes with all his heart to keep the world in safety.
And these organizations, so varied in composition, who
have joined in the strike, have shown that they regard
the threat of war as bigger than their minor differences.
They have shown that they regard the fight for peace
as something more than the personal property of some
foreign peril—whether it be Black, Yellow, or Red.

Dr. Joseph D. H. Donnay, associate in mineralogy at the Johns Hopkins University, has been bequeathed
a collection of thousands of measured crystals together with unpublished notebooks and records by the
late Dr. Henri Ungemach, eminent
Alsatian crystallographer and secretary of the gocidte franeais de Mineralogie.
The collection, representing many
years of painstaking labor by the
French scientist, consists of about
2,500 carefully numbered vials each
holding from one to three tiny,
mounted crystals. It is accompanied by thirty-six notebooks containing large freehand sketches of each
crystal type, and the goniometric
measurements of the angles between
the faces of each crystal.
Dr. Donnay first met Dr. Ungemach, with whom he had been corresponding for some years, at Strasbourg, France, last summer, and
discussed with him the projected revision of Dana's "System of Mineralogy" to which Dr. Donnay is contributing. It was, however, their
mutual interest in the problem of
forms and the internal structure of
the relationship between the external
crystals—and Dr. Donnay's accomplishments in this field—which led Dr.
Ungemach to bequeath his collection
and notebooks to Dr. Donnay. Although this was a personal legacy
to him, Dr. Donnay placed the material at the disposal of the Harvard
mineralogists who are working on
the new "Dana" text.
Discovers Law
Last November, Dr. Donnay, in
collaboration with Dr. David Harker
of the Chemistry faculty, discovered
a new law of crystallography correlating satisfactorily the internal
structure and external morphology of
crystals.
An abstract of this discovery was
presented, last January, before a
meeting of the Academie des Sciences
at Paris. When he returned to Baltimore, Dr. Donnay brought the mineral legacy with him. Within the
next few years he expects to prepare and publish much of the great
volume of valuable data contained
in the notebooks. The first two of
the papers to be based upon the findings and plans of Dr. Ungemach will
be a study of the ruby silvers—the
minerals pyrargyrite and proustite
—and a study of North African
minerals.

Everyone Should Attend
Every student who is interested in the recent Phi
Bete case—and who wants to do something about it—
should attend the protest meeting this afternoon at one
o'clock. And everyone should be interested. A goodly
portion of the student body is affected by Phi Beta
Kappa per se. But all of us should interest ourselves in
this case, because it is a real student problem. Whether
justified or not, the campus is interpreting the facts in
this case to mean that one must forgo this type of
academic recognition if one wants to be in the leadership of a progressive movement. And that is the impression which must be corrected—if there is no
foundation for it.
If there is any information to be obtained or ideas
to be exchanged, attend this meeting. If you think our
stand is unfair or unjustified, let us know. One of the
ways to settle this problem is to intelligently exchange
ideas and consider the situation carefully.
There is no doubt that in order to get something done
we have to crystallize our sentiment. We have to show
that we students are concerned with an apparent injustice for this case and to seek a non-recurrence in the
future.

Editorial In Verse
We have received a poem which expresses a sentiment
more effectively than a most verbose editorial. It makes
you stop and think about the motto of our University.
Just what are the practical implications of
"Veritas vos liberabit,"
This poem attempts to take an inventory of the
guiding ideal of our University. We do not necessarily
agree with all of its contentions, but are in accordance
with the spirit behind it.
"Veritas vos liberabit,"
The truth shall make you free!
0 men of Hopkins,
That meant something once
To our University.
Or did it?
At any rate,
It means very little now.
Let our Pilate ask,
What is truth?
Pilates have always asked that,
As they have barricaded themselves
Within the walls of their own smallness
And washed their hands in their own watery blood.
Even if truth
Be not absolute,
Even if it be only a propositional function,
Or only a frame of reference,
It is something more than a matter of politics,
Of personal pettiness,
Of pettifogging poltroons,
Of priggish pusillanimity.
If it be only a point of view,
Still must we look at it through hate-colored glasses?
And to me it seems
That if there is no truth,
There are some truths,
Honor, fair-mindedness, courage, strength.
If I am wrong,
It is a grand way to be wrong.
But, my friends,
When lucre becomes more than light
And animosity more than appraisal,
It takes more than truth to make you free.

Even those students who have been here only a short

Support The Peace Strike
With hardly three weeks left before this year's Student Strike against War, only twelve of the thirty-odd
eligible campus organizations have expressed any sympathy with its aims. Thus, more than half the more
active section of the student .body has no representation
on the strike committee.
Can it be that these organizations are opposed to
peace as a principle? But, in every poll on the question
in •the last few years, the Hopkins has manifested a
deep-seated distaste for Mars and all his works.
There is another more likely possibility. Is this
apathy indicative of the feeling that, behind the strike's
innocent exterior, subversive forces are moving? In
other words, the claim is that we who support the strike
have been duped by agents of some foreign ideology.
That contention is best answered by the list of organizations now represented on the committee. They are,
at last account, the Student Council, the Hullabaloo,
Omicron Delta Kappa, the NEWS-LETTER, the Debating
Council, -the Y.M.C.A., the Student Activities Committee,
Phi Sigma Delta, Phi Alpha, Phi Epsilon Pi, the Young
Communist League, and the American Student Union.
Of these, only the last two can, •by any stretch of the
imagination, be influenced by radical opinion. Three,
in fact, are social fraternities, traditionally the chief
object of attack from the left. The ratio is ten to two—
hardly an overwhelming preponderance for "unsafe"
opinions.
The truth is, of course, that the questions of war and
peace transcend political lines. Every decent citizen
hopes with all his heart to keep the world in safety.
And these organizations, so varied in composition, who
have joined in the strike, have shown that they regard
the threat of war as bigger than their minor differences.
They have shown that they regard the fight for peace
as something more than the personal property of some
foreign peril—whether it be Black, Yellow, or Red.

America has arisen to the pleading cry of the trampled
upon masses of true Americans. No longer will we
have to sit by and watch "lawless trade unions" and

and other "subversive elements" getting a strangle-hold
upon true American democracy and building up a
dictatorship. NO, fellows, Captain Edward Page Gaston,

going to pursue them with the same relentless spirit
with which he tracked down the thousands of trunks
abandoned by American tourists fleeing in 1919 from
the war stricken countries.
As a staunch friend of the pee-pul and as one of the
heads of the (ssssh!) the inner confidential circle of this
nationalizing movement, Capt. Page, RESERVE, is
going to end the "cringing under the last of demagogues" of our rulers. Yes, he is organizing an auxiliary force to the U. S. Army with, of course, the Captain (Diplomatically derived) as the head, since such
men as General Pershing have unfortunately been
unable to accept this position due to "health and other
preoccupations."

thinking of the ridiculousness of IL

it can be saved if our loyal people dare to get a strangle
hold upon those who now have a strangle hold upon us."

and recognize the menaces in America today.

Dr. Joseph D. H. Donnay, associate in mineralogy at the Johns Hopkins University, has been bequeathed
a collection of thousands of measured crystals together with unpublished notebooks and records by the
late Dr. Henri Ungemach, eminent
Alsatian crystallographer and secretary of the gocidte franeais de Mineralogie.
The collection, representing many
years of painstaking labor by the
French scientist, consists of about
2,500 carefully numbered vials each
holding from one to three tiny,
mounted crystals. It is accompanied by thirty-six notebooks containing large freehand sketches of each
crystal type, and the goniometric
measurements of the angles between
the faces of each crystal.
Dr. Donnay first met Dr. Ungemach, with whom he had been corresponding for some years, at Strasbourg, France, last summer, and
discussed with him the projected revision of Dana's "System of Mineralogy" to which Dr. Donnay is contributing. It was, however, their
mutual interest in the problem of
forms and the internal structure of
the relationship between the external
crystals—and Dr. Donnay's accomplishments in this field—which led Dr.
Ungemach to bequeath his collection
and notebooks to Dr. Donnay. Although this was a personal legacy
to him, Dr. Donnay placed the material at the disposal of the Harvard
mineralogists who are working on
the new "Dana" text.
Discovers Law
Last November, Dr. Donnay, in
collaboration with Dr. David Harker
of the Chemistry faculty, discovered
a new law of crystallography correlating satisfactorily the internal
structure and external morphology of
crystals.
An abstract of this discovery was
presented, last January, before a
meeting of the Academie des Sciences
at Paris. When he returned to Baltimore, Dr. Donnay brought the mineral legacy with him. Within the
next few years he expects to prepare and publish much of the great
volume of valuable data contained
in the notebooks. The first two of
the papers to be based upon the findings and plans of Dr. Ungemach will
be a study of the ruby silvers—the
minerals pyrargyrite and proustite
—and a study of North African
minerals.

Pushkin

Festival will be held April 16, at
8:30 P. M., in Latrobe Hall. The
one hundredth

anniversary of the

death of the great Russian poet and
playwright will be marked by a musical program and a short address by
Dr. James Bunyan, Fellow in the
Page School of International Relations.

The music program is under

the direction of Dr. Lubov Keefer,
now teaching Musical History at
the Hopkins, and connected with the
Peabody Institute.
The concert will be composed of
numbers based on the poetry and librettos of the prolific writer. Although not a musician himself, Pushkin's poetry has inspired many of
the world's greatest composers. The
artists to be heard will be Mrs. Anna
Breit, soprano; Polydoros Komianos,
violinist; Stuart le Compte, Jr., baritone, and Dr. Keefer, pianist. The
selections are not announced yet.
Dr. N. B. Fagin, director of the
Playshop, and organizer of this festival, will preside at the meeting. The
earlier plans to include dramatic
readings by the members of the Playshop have been changed, to permit a
more complete treatment of the musical side of the program.
Pushkin, killed in a duel in 1837,
was perhaps the greatest of Russian
poets. His works also include several librettos, the best-known of
which are "Boris Goudenov," and
"Eugene Onegin." Both have been
performed by the Metropolitan Opera
'Company of New York. He wrote
several novels, including the famous "Queen of Spades," a lighter
work, which has been adopted to the
comic opera stage.
Dr. Keefer, in charge of the musical program, took her degree in
German at the Hopkins, and has
since been active in musical circles
of Baltimore.
